concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure in certain cases of false evidence

anchor.surface_text: Section 479-A was incorporated into the Code of Criminal Procedure by Act 26 of 1955. That section reads 479-A. Procedure in certain cases of false evidence. Notwithstanding anything companytained in sections 476 to 479 inclusive when any Civil, Revenue or Criminal Court is of opinion that any person appearing before it as a witness has intentionally fabricated false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of the judicial proceeding, and that, for the eradication of the evils of perjury and fabrication of false evidence and in the interests of justice, it is expedient that such witness should be prosecuted for the offence which appears to have been companymitted by him, the Court shall, at the time of the delivery of the judgment or final order disposing of such proceeding, record a finding to that effect stating its reasons therefore and may, if it so thinks fit, after giving the witness an opportunity of being heard, make a companyplaint thereof in writing signed by the presiding officer of the, Court setting forth the evidence which in the opinion of the Court is false or fabricated and forward the same to a Magistrate of the first class having jurisdiction and may if the accused is present before the Court, take sufficient security for his appearance before such Magistrate and may bind over any person to appear and give evidence before such Magistrate Provided that where the Court making the company- plaint is a High Court the companyplaint may be signed by such officer of the Court as the Court may appoint.

issues.text: whether the requirements of Section 479-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure have been complied with before instituting the complaint from which this appeal arises and if they have not been complied with whether the prosecution is vitiated

anchor.surface_text: The only substantial question that arises for decision in this appeal by special leave is as to whether the requirements of Section 479-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure have been complied with before instituting the complaint from which this appeal arises

issues.text: whether the explanation given by the appellant in the dacoity case as well as his evidence in that case are inadmissible in the present proceedings

anchor.surface_text: We also do not find any merit in the contention that the explanation given by the appellant in the dacoity case as well as his evidence in that case are inadmissible, in the present proceedings.

issues.text: whether after arriving at the findings [under Section 479-A] and before filing the complaint, the learned Sessions Judge had given [the appellant] an opportunity to show cause why complaint should not be filed against him and whether that requirement is mandatory

anchor.surface_text: But according to the appellant, the complaint is vitiated because after arriving at the findings in question and before filing the complaint, the learned Sessions Judge had not given him an opportunity to show cause why complaint should not be filed against him.

arguments.claim: The complaint is vitiated because after arriving at the findings under Section 479-A and before filing the complaint, the Sessions Judge did not give the appellant an opportunity to show cause why the complaint should not be filed, and this requirement is mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: But according to the appellant, the complaint is vitiated because after arriving at the findings in question and before filing the complaint, the learned Sessions Judge had not given him an opportunity to show cause why complaint should not be filed against him.

arguments.court_reasoning: The provision uses 'may, if it so thinks fit, after giving the witness an opportunity', making it discretionary for trial court, unlike mandatory for appellate court under sub-s(5). Earlier opportunity was given.

arguments.claim: Under Section 479-A(1), the court is bound to give opportunity to show cause after findings and before complaint, as per Kuppa Goundan v. M. S. P. Rajesh.

arguments.claim: Requirements of Section 479-A were complied with as trial court recorded necessary findings and opportunity is discretionary under 'may, if it so thinks fit'.

anchor.surface_text: This provision clearly shows that what is mandatory is that the judge must give a finding that the witness has intentionally given false evidence... Giving of an opportunity to the witness to show cause against the contemplated complaint is not mandatory.

arguments.claim: Distinction between trial court (discretionary opportunity) and appellate court (mandatory under sub-s(5)) explains the legislative scheme.

anchor.surface_text: This position is made further clear when we go to sub- section 5 of Section 479-A... In other words in the case of the trial court a discretion is given... but so far as the appellate court is concerned the giving of an opportunity... is made mandatory.

arguments.claim: Section 479-A introduced to eradicate evils of perjury by allowing direct complaint without old procedure in ss 476-479.

anchor.surface_text: Section 479-A was incorporated into the Code of Criminal Procedure by Act 26 of 1955... This section was introduced into the Code with the idea of eradicating to the extent possible the evils of perjury and fabrication of false evidence

arguments.claim: Adequate opportunity was given earlier to appellant prima facie before final findings.

arguments.claim: Admissions in prior proceedings are substantive evidence unless disproved.

anchor.surface_text: Admissions made in the explanation given and in the deposition are relevant and admissible in the present case. An admission is a substantive evidence, though it is open to the person who made the admission to show that the fact admitted is not correct.

arguments.claim: Appellant intentionally gave false evidence and fabricated as he knew the real Abdul Gani well.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the admissions made by the appellant during the Sessions Trial... that he knew Abdul Gani very well. Therefore there was no occasion for him to make any mistake.

arguments.claim: View accords with Madras HC in Rukmani Bai and AP HC in Rc. Javvaji Uthanna that opportunity not mandatory under 479A(1).

holdings.text: Under Section 479-A(5), giving opportunity to show cause before complaint is mandatory for appellate courts, distinguishing from trial courts.

holdings.text: Adequate opportunity was given to the appellant earlier prima facie before final findings, satisfying natural justice even if post-finding hearing desirable.

holdings.text: The prosecution is not vitiated for non-compliance with Section 479-A as all requirements fulfilled.
